monogr.title: A Digital Dictionary of Shawi Arabic

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the teiCorpusHeader prefix are pointers to any element in the SHAWI teiCorpus document.
Private URIs using the share prefix are pointers to audio file residing on the SHAWI network share.
Private URIs using the geo prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a place element in VICAV Geodata list.
Private URIs using the zotid prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a biblStruct element in the TEI export of the VICAV Zotero Group library.
Private URIs using the dict prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a entry in the SHAWI glossary.
Private URIs using the rend prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a rendition element in VICAV rendition library.
Private URIs using the assets prefix are pointers to the location of the SHAWI media assets.
Private URIs using the assets prefix are pointers to the location of the SHAWI media assets.

spanGrp.span: I went to Ankara with the passport to get a visa – a visa to Syria? – to Syria, when it still was in Ankara.

Ḥāfiḏ̣ al-Asad’s son called Bassām – Baššār – had died. – Bāṣil, Bāṣil – Yes, Bāṣim. When he died, one of my uncles died as well, some people died there, and now my family wanted to go there to show condolence.

It was winter, raining, and cold. There was no money; but she was crying and said, “I want to go no matter what! Some of my relatives are dead” I was trying to convince her to change her mind, but she said, “No!”
I was looking for a way out (to settle this). “Oh, patient God!” I had to get a passport issued, but I did not have money for the transportation.
Many Arabs used to go to Istanbul. I took off from the city of Urfa then I changed in Osmaniye, where there were Arabs.
I spent the night there. They got me on board in the morning, they paid for the bus ticket to Adana.
I got off in Adana and spent the night there at the place of the Bani Nm¬ēr, at Ḥāǧǧ Ḥamze, may God rest his soul.
In the morning he got me on the bus to Ankara. He bought me a ticket and said goodbye, so I went to Ankara
When I got off it was the sunrise and cold. I went to the consul, what is it called, where the consul is?
Çankaya – Çankaya, I went there, but it was not opened yet. No one was there.
The guard called me. “Hey what’s the matter? Come here!” I went to him, he was in a cottage, a guard at the consul. I said to him, “Passport, passport.”
No one is here now. The consul comes at 9 o’clock. Till 9, 10 o’clock
He looked at me. I felt cold, it was raining. He said, “Are you cold?” I said, “Yes.” He opened the thing, there was a stove and a chair. I sat down.
There was a coffee maker, he called him. He gave me a cigarette. I felt cold and tired. I had come from afar. I fell asleep.
It was 9 o’clock and I was still sleeping. He woke me up. “Fellow countryman, the consul has arrived. There is a hustle and bustle.”
I went there and he started to give me some papers. Anyway, I filled the papers and handed them over.
“Where is the applicant for the passport? The owner of the passport, where is she?” I said, “She is from the family. She is my wife, and she is at home.”
He said, “I do not want to do it. She has to come,” I begged him: Urfa is far away from Ankara. I am poor, I have no money.
“Who sent you here must sign it herself.” I begged him. (He said,) “I do not want to do it, who sent you here, must do it.”
“Well, who sent me is the government. It should do it, you should do it!” – “No, she must come here.” At that time Tansu Çiller was the prime minister, a woman.
“Please, I beg you!” He said, “Who sent you here, must do it!” I said, “Tansu Čiller, Tamsōn has given the order to go.
